greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Expansion of (1 - x) * (1 - x^4) / (1 - x^5) in powers of x.
comment: This sequence with a(0) replaced by 2 appears, together with three other sequences, in the formula 2*exp(2*Pi*n*I/5) = 2*T(n,x) + S(n-1,x)*sqrt(2+phi)*I, with x = (phi-1)/2 and I  = sqrt(-1), where phi = (1+sqrt(5))/2 (golden section) after reduction of powers using phi^2 = phi+1. T and S are Chebyshev polynomials from A053120 and A049310. This results in 2*exp(2*Pi*n*I/5) = (A(n) + B(n)*phi) + (C(n) + D(n)*phi)*sqrt(2+phi)*I, with A(n) = a(n+5), B(n) = A080891(n), C(n) = A156174(n+4) and D(n) = A010891(n+3) for n >= 0. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Feb 26 2014
link: G. C. Greubel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
formula: a(n) = a(-n) for all n in Z. a(n+5) = a(n) unless n=0 or n=-5.
a(n) = (-1)^n * A164118(n). Convolution inverse of A164115.
example: exp(2*Pi*3*I/5) = (0 - phi) + (1 - phi)*sqrt(2+phi)*I, with phi = (1+sqrt(5))/2. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Feb 26 2014
program: (MAGMA) m:=50; R<x>:=PowerSeriesRing(Integers(), m); Coefficients(R!((1 - x^4)/(1+x+x^2+x^3+x^4))); // _G. C. Greubel_, Sep 22 2018
results.author: _Michael Somos_, Aug 10 2009
